content.title: Twin-Twin Transfusion Syndrome - Laser Ablation
content.definition: Fetoscopic laser photocoagulation of placental anastomoses for treatment of twin-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS) in monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies.

key_concepts.description: Unbalanced blood flow through placental arteriovenous anastomoses from donor to recipient twin, causing donor oligohydramnios/anemia and recipient polyhydramnios/cardiac overload.
Stage I: Polyhydramnios/oligohydramnios. Stage II: Absent bladder in donor. Stage III: Abnormal Dopplers. Stage IV: Hydrops. Stage V: Fetal demise.
Arterioarterial (AA), venovenous (VV), and arteriovenous (AV) connections. AV anastomoses are responsible for TTTS.

indications.standard: Stage II-IV TTTS between 16-26 weeks gestation
indications.relative: Stage I with progression, severe polyhydramnios causing maternal symptoms
indications.contraindications: Gestational age >26 weeks (relative), severe fetal anomalies, cervical incompetence

approach.access: Fetoscopic via percutaneous port (3-4mm) under ultrasound guidance
approach.entry: Into recipient sac (polyhydramnios provides working space)
approach.anesthesia: Local with maternal sedation, or regional

procedure.ablation: Laser photocoagulation of crossing vessels using Nd:YAG or diode laser

techniques.solomon: Ablate anastomoses plus dichorionize placenta (line connecting ablation sites)

surgical_technique.amnioreduction: Drain excess amniotic fluid from recipient sac at end of procedure

vascular_surgery_role.consultation: Vascular surgeons may be consulted for understanding vascular anastomosis patterns
vascular_surgery_role.collaboration: Procedure primarily performed by maternal-fetal medicine specialists with fetal surgery training
vascular_surgery_role.knowledge_base: Understanding of arteriovenous fistula physiology relevant

outcomes.versus_amnioreduction: Superior survival with laser vs serial amnioreduction alone

complications.fetal_demise: 5-10% of one twin, often within 24-48 hours

citations: Senat MV, et al. Endoscopic laser surgery versus serial amnioreduction for severe twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome. N Engl J Med. 2004;351(2):136-144

learning_objectives: Explain the pathophysiology of TTTS and role of placental anastomoses
Outline the fetoscopic laser ablation technique
Discuss outcomes and complications of laser treatment
clinical_pearls: TTTS is a disease of vascular anastomoses - understanding AVF physiology helps
Procedure performed by specialized fetal surgery centers
Vascular surgeons may contribute to multidisciplinary team discussions
